Here are some steps caregivers can take to teach a four-year-old how to read:

1. Create a positive and encouraging learning environment. Make reading fun and interactive by using songs, rhymes, and games.
2. Begin with the basics. Teach the child the alphabet, including the names and sounds of each letter.
3. Introduce simple words and phrases. Start with words and phrases that are familiar to the child, such as their name and the names of family members.
4. Encourage reading aloud. Help the child practice reading by sounding out words and phrases.
5. Provide plenty of opportunities to read. Encourage the child to read books, signs, and labels, and to read aloud to you or a stuffed animal.
6. Be patient and don't put too much pressure. Keep in mind that every child learns at their own pace.
7. Use various teaching methods, some children may learn better with visual aids and others with hands-on activities.
8. Praise and reward progress, even small steps.

It's also important to note that it's not only the caregivers responsibility, but also the parents and teachers to work together to provide the best possible learning environment for the child.
